Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
> On 6/11/02 8:31 AM, "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > The GUI is itself a framework composed of components (widgets) that each
> > encapsulate state. For example:
> > - contents, labels
> > - enabled/disabled
> > - shown/hidden
> > - color, font
> > - etc.
>
> Yes.
> >
> > In order to change the state of those components there must be a
> > conversation from the model, or mediator in your example, to
> those widgets.
>
> Yes.
>
> > This conversation is typically implemented in > 0 lines of
> nontrivial code.
> > This code is prone to breakage.
>
> In general, I don't agree. If you are doing anything more than
> making swing
> calls, that code should be elsewhere. When the code is not
> trivial, which I
> claim is rare (and I do this for a living), then test the gui. I'm not
> saying don't test it - I'm saying question if the test is needed. If it's
> needed, do it. If you can move the logic elsewhere, then just
> look at it to
> see if it works.
>
> >
> > On top of that you also have the conversation from the widgets to the
> > model/mediator. This also is prone to breakage, typically through
> > inappropriate use of listener callback arguments, or just
> simply forgetting
> > to set up a callback.
> >
>
> Which would be highly visible and immediately obvious that it wasn't
> working.
>
> > So you see, the statement that it "can't break" is just a bit overly
> > optimistic.
> >
>
> Perhaps, but not to the extent that you're implying.

Given:
1) You acknowledge that for some cases there is a greater than zero
likelehood that the connection to a GUI can be coded incorrectly
2) You work for ObjectMentor, which promotes XP practices
3) XP mandates that we test anything that can break

I conclude that you agree that testing at the GUI layer for some cases is a
good thing.

Perhaps the next task is to identify which GUI implementation patterns are
more prone to breakage and suggest the need for GUI-driven test cases.
